quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 12 Quiz 9
quiz.subtitle: 12.9: Coordination Isomerism
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Structural and stereoisomerism in complex ions

questions.question: Which type of isomerism occurs when an ambidentate ligand can coordinate to the metal through different atoms?
questions.explanation: Linkage isomerism involves ligands like $NO_{2}^{-}$ which can bind via N (nitro) or O (nitrito).

questions.question: What is the difference between $[Co(NH_{3})_{5}Br]SO_{4}$ and $[Co(NH_{3})_{5}SO_{4}]Br$?
questions.explanation: Ionization isomers differ in which species acts as the ligand versus the counter-ion in the crystal lattice.

questions.question: Geometric isomerism (cis/trans) is most commonly observed in which coordination geometries?
questions.explanation: Tetrahedral complexes do not show cis/trans isomerism because all positions are equidistant from one another.

questions.question: In an octahedral complex of the type $MA_{3}B_{3}$, which two geometric isomers are possible?
questions.explanation: Facial isomers have three identical ligands on one triangular face; meridional isomers have them forming a 'belt' around the center.

questions.question: What defines a pair of 'enantiomers' in coordination chemistry?
options: They differ only by the orientation of a single ligand.
questions.explanation: Enantiomers (optical isomers) rotate plane-polarized light in opposite directions and cannot be rotated to look identical.

questions.question: Which of the following complexes is likely to exhibit optical isomerism?
questions.explanation: Tris-bidentate complexes like $[Co(en)_{3}]^{3+}$ form 'propeller' shapes that lack a plane of symmetry.

questions.question: Coordination isomerism occurs in compounds where:
options: Both the cation and the anion are complex ions.
Water molecules are exchanged between the sphere and the lattice.
The metal changes its oxidation state.
Ligands swap positions within a single coordination sphere.
questions.explanation: In coordination isomerism, ligands are redistributed between the two complex ion parts of the salt.

questions.question: Hydrate isomerism is a specific subtype of:
questions.explanation: Hydrate isomerism involves the exchange of water molecules between the inner coordination sphere and the outer crystal structure.

questions.question: The 'trans' isomer of $[Pt(NH_{3})_{2}Cl_{2}]$ (cisplatin/transplatin) is different from the 'cis' isomer because:
options: Identical ligands are opposite (180°) to each other.
Identical ligands are adjacent (90°) to each other.
The chlorine atoms are replaced by water.
The platinum atom is in a +4 oxidation state.
questions.explanation: In trans isomers, the identical groups are positioned at opposite poles of the metal center.

questions.question: Why do square planar complexes of the type $MA_{2}B_{2}$ NOT show optical isomerism?
options: They possess a plane of symmetry.
questions.explanation: Square planar molecules are flat (2D), meaning the molecular plane itself acts as a plane of symmetry, preventing chirality.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a sharp eye for molecular symmetry.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Remember to distinguish between structural and stereoisomers.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Review the fac/mer and cis/trans requirements.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the definitions of linkage, ionization, and geometric isomerism.
